qas.question: What Chinese dialect has more consonants than standard Mandarin or Cantonese?

plausible_answers.text: one of the most diverse phoneme inventories

context: <a0_0><b5_0><b7_0>Hokkien<b7_0/><b5_0/><a0_0/> has <b8_0>one of the most diverse <a3_0>phoneme inventories<b8_0/><a3_0/> among Chinese varieties, with <b12_0>more <b4_0>consonants<b12_0/><b4_0/> than Standard Mandarin or Cantonese. Vowels are <b9_0>more-or-less <a1_0>similar<b9_0/><a1_0/> to that of Standard Mandarin. Hokkien varieties retain <a2_0><b6_0><b10_0>many pronunciations<b10_0/><b6_0/><a2_0/> that are no longer found in other Chinese varieties. These include the retention of the /t/ initial, which is now <b11_0>/tʂ/ (Pinyin 'zh')<b11_0/> in Mandarin (e.g. 'bamboo' 竹 is tik, but zhú in Mandarin), having disappeared before the 6th century in other Chinese varieties.
